bibl.author: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman
bibl.title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [16 February 1869]

revisionDesc.change: Transcribe surface 4, from original at Duke
Proofreading Corrections: Heyde dates and Silent Proof
Clean encoding (editor, date, remove "_large") and add standard annotations on unannotated files (Jeff W, Martha [Mattie], George W, Lou Haslam)

body.p:
I was so glad Walt to hear you was better of the distress in your head the carrier was later than usual and georgeGeorge came home to his dinner and said he saw a carrier in Bedford aven Avenue so i thought you was worse and the thoughts that run through my head in five minutes you would laughf laugh if i told you georgeGeorge said if you was sick you would get somebody to write
just then the bell rang and the letter man called out mrsMrs. Whitman then i thought how foolish i was to be worried before i knew any thing to be worried about)

i have had a letter from Heyde he says han is well except her hand he says she dont don't give it a chance to get well she sews and works they have got a french girl he says she is a dirty brute that is his
expression and he shall change again i felt very glad even to hear from him) i think really han might write as i have requested her so much her right hand she could write a few lines anyhow i hope you wont won't have no more of those spels spells walterWalter dear i got the letter and money all safe and very acceptable as i was rather short) georgeyGeorgey having parted with nearly all he had he expectdedexpected a draft
from Jeff but it didentdidn't come he never had such difficulydifficulty in getting money before he is working now but he has tried all over to get a loan on smiths house but failed to get any lottLott has tried his best but failed) if Jeff dontdon't send him the draft) he will have to raise it some how but I think very likely he will send it) O waltWalt i am out of envelopes this is the last one i am as well as usual anna vanwyckAnna VanWyck and lib was to see me the other day
